awd_titl_txt: The Fluid Mechanics of Bacterial Swimming in Yield Stress Fluids
awd_abstract_narration:
Biological fluids such as mucous can behave like elastic solids or complex viscous liquid depending on the applied stress.  The goal of this project is to understand the fluid mechanics of bacterial swimming in model complex fluids that resemble biological fluids. This comprehensive theoretical, computational, and experimental study will fill an important knowledge gap in understanding the relationship between the properties of biological fluids and the mechanics of bacterial motility. Swimming capabilities significantly contribute to the virulence of pathogenic bacteria by allowing them to reach the plasma membrane of susceptible cells and cause systemic infections. Therefore, data acquired in the project will be useful to researchers who want to mitigate or treat bacterial diseases.  It will also be crucial for bioengineers aiming to deliver drugs via bacteria or synthetic swimmers.  In addition, the project will provide outreach that inspires interest in engineering among K-12 students by illustrating the societal impact of engineering science. 

Bacterial motility in biological fluids such as mucous is complicated by the presence of a yield stress, a minimal stress necessary to deform the fluid, the coupled viscous and elastic responses of the fluid, and the non-continuum nature arising because the bacterium’s flagella have a thickness comparable with the spacing between mucus strands.  A novel computational approach accounting for this complex rheology will capture the bacterium cell using an immersed boundary method and the bundle of flagella using slender-body theory.  The solvent and polymer will be modeled as two interpenetrating fluids with the thin flagella exerting their stresses directly only on the solvent.   In complementary experiments, nanoparticle organic hybrid bio-compatible materials will be designed with rheology and structure that mimic the biological fluids.  Dark-field and phase-contrast microscopy of suspensions of E. coli will provide statistically accurate measurements of the swimming speed and cell rotation rate distribution.  In microscopy tracking individual cells, separate fluorescent dyes will enable the determination of the different rotation rates of the cell and flagella bundle.  Observations in Newtonian fluids will be used to characterize the rotary motors that drive the flagella. The motility measurements will be performed in collaboration with Professor Wilson Poon at the University of Edinburgh.  The experiments will determine the criterion for cells to swim, the speed of cells that do swim, and the distinct resistances the non-continuum fluid exert on the cell and flagella, thereby testing three crucial predictions of the computation and theory.

por.por_cntn:
The fluid mechanics of bacterial swimming in yield stress fluids

Biological fluids like mucus possess a complex structure and exhibit both elastic solid and viscous liquid behaviors, depending on the applied stress. This project aimed to advance our understanding of how bacteria swim through such fluids by integrating theoretical modeling, computational simulations, and laboratory experiments. Our findings provide critical insights into bacterial motion in mucus-like environments, with applications in medicine, bioengineering, and microbiology.

Intellectual Merit

This research made significant contributions to fluid mechanics, microbiology, and computational modeling by:

  • Developing a novel theoretical framework to model bacterial motility in complex biological fluids.
  • Creating advanced computational simulations to study bacterial swimming in yield-stress and viscoelastic fluids.
  • Designing and characterizing bio-compatible yield-stress fluids that mimic real biological mucus.
  • Conducting microscopy-based experimental studies to validate theoretical predictions on bacterial motion.

These contributions help fill a knowledge gap in understanding how the properties of biological fluids influence bacterial locomotion. The computational models and experimental platforms developed in this work will serve as valuable resources for future research in biological and synthetic fluid dynamics.

Broader Impacts

The broader impacts of this project extend across multiple disciplines and societal applications, including:

Biomedical Applications

Understanding how bacteria move in mucus-like fluids has important implications for infectious disease research and treatment. Our findings may contribute to new strategies for controlling bacterial infections, developing improved antimicrobial treatments, and designing synthetic micro-swimmers for targeted drug delivery in complex biological environments.

Education and Workforce Development

This project provided hands-on training for three PhD students, one MSc student, and two undergraduate students, equipping them with interdisciplinary expertise in microbiology, fluid mechanics, and computational modeling. Additionally, project findings were integrated into undergraduate coursework and outreach programs for K-12 students, fostering early interest in STEM fields.

Technology and Materials Science

The bio-compatible yield-stress fluids developed in this study have potential applications beyond biology. These materials could be used in biomedical coatings, industrial lubricants, and soft robotics, opening doors for future technological innovations.

Advancements in Computational and Experimental Techniques

We developed a new numerical framework combining slender-body theory and two-fluid modeling to simulate bacterial swimming in non-Newtonian environments. This computational tool, along with experimental datasets generated from microscopy-based bacterial motility studies, enhances institutional research infrastructure and provides valuable resources for future studies.

Key Findings

  • Artificial mucus development: We successfully designed and characterized a synthetic bio-compatible mucus-like fluid to systematically study bacterial motility.
  • Theoretical modeling of bacterial swimming: We formulated a slender-body theory for bacteria swimming in polymeric solutions and identified key fluid-structure interactions.
  • Computational simulations: A novel hybrid theoretical-computational approach was created to simulate bacterial movement in mucus-like environments, considering viscoelasticity, yield stress, and microstructure.
  • Experimental validation: Laboratory experiments confirmed theoretical predictions and provided quantitative measurements of bacterial swimming speeds in different complex fluids.
  • Rheology of yield-stress fluids: The project characterized the flow behavior of nanoparticle-based fluids, contributing to the broader field of soft matter physics.

Conclusion

This project has advanced fundamental knowledge on bacterial motility in mucus-like fluids while generating practical tools for microbiology, medicine, and engineering. The findings have implications for disease control, bio-inspired robotics, and synthetic fluid design, laying the groundwork for future interdisciplinary research in biological fluid mechanics.

By combining theory, computation, and experiments, this work provides a comprehensive framework for studying microorganisms in complex environments and contributes to the broader goal of understanding and manipulating bacterial motion in biological and synthetic systems.
